report_title: Peanut Butter Production in the US
executive_summary: Over the five years to 2022, revenue for the Peanut Butter Production industry has decreased at an annualized rate of 3.5% to $2.1 billion, including a 2.1% decrease in 2022 alone. The industry experienced gains in 2017 and 2021 as the disposable income of consumers rose and the popularity of peanut butter.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Increased Automation and Shifting Industry Structure
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Peanut butter production is moderately capital-intensive and relies on heavy machinery to maximize productivity. A typical peanut butter plant uses a conveyer-belt system that takes shelled peanuts through a process of roasting, cooling, blanching, splitting, grinding and mixing, before the end product is jarred and shipped. Technological advancements over the past few decades have helped producers automate many of the processes traditionally performed by labor, further increasing the industry's reliance on capital.

Overall demand for industry products increased during a portion of the current period, driven by favorable consumer trends such as rising health consciousness, increased snacking and the growing popularity of high-protein diets that include peanuts and other tree nuts. Over the past five years, many peanut butter producers have expanded their product range to capitalize on these trends.

While the United States is one of the largest exporters of peanut butter in the world, international trade plays a relatively minor role within the industry. The United States is the world's largest consumer of peanut butter; however, most production is consumed domestically. Furthermore, exports have grown over the past five years, increasing at an annualized rate of 1.5% to $136.9 million due to growing interest in US-produced peanut butter.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The wholesale price of peanuts is difficult to forecast because it depends on various external factors, such as the weather and price of substitute crops. If the price of cotton, corn or soybeans increases dramatically, farmers may shift to these alternate crops, which could lead to a peanut shortage and a subsequent spike in the price of peanuts.

Wages are expected to increase at an annualized rate of 0.8% to $185.1 million over the next five years. The industry will likely continue its drive toward automation to achieve higher a profit margin. In particular, major industry operators are projected to attempt to drive down labor costs through new plant investments.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry primarily manufacture peanut butter. Industry products are then packaged and distributed to grocery wholesalers, supermarkets, specialty food stores and food service contractors for human consumption. The industry excludes peanut butter made by manufacturers for use in their own candy and snacks.

opportunities: Demand from supermarkets and grocery stores
threats: Low Performance Drivers: Agricultural price index

key_trends: This industry is characterized by an exceptional level of brand loyalty
Product innovation to satisfy changing consumer preferences is essential to remain competitive
The market dominance of the most popular US peanut butter brands limits demand for foreign-made products
Peanut butter is anticipated to remain a widely accepted consumer staple
The trend toward premium peanut butter consumption is likely to continue

market_segmentation.segment_description: Sales to warehouse clubs and supercenters account for an estimated 34.3% of industry revenue in 2022.
Supermarkets and grocery stores are the primary locations where industry products are sold, comprising 32.1% of sales in 2022.
Grocery wholesalers purchase peanut butter from producers and resell to retailers, accounting for 15.5% of industry sales in 2022.
Convenience stores and gas stations enable consumers to purchase peanut butter while traveling, comprising 11.7% of sales in 2022.
Exports account for an estimated 6.4% of total industry revenue in 2022.

products_and_services.product_description: Crunchy peanut butter has chunks of peanuts incorporated into a creamy peanut butter base. Less popular than creamy.
Creamy peanut butter is made by grinding peanuts into a paste before adding oil, salt and sugar. More versatile for new formats.
Includes flavored peanut butters like chocolate, portion packs for convenience, natural/organic varieties, and other new product innovations.

tier_1_suppliers: Plastic Bottle Manufacturing in the US
Glass Product Manufacturing in the US
Syrup & Flavoring Production in the US
Fruit & Nut Farming in the US
Seasoning, Sauce and Condiment Production in the US
tier_2_buyers: Supermarkets & Grocery Stores in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Peanut butter as a household staple
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Peanut butter has a reputation in the US as a universally liked food that even children readily accept. It is perceived as a household staple due to being an affordable source of protein with a long shelf life.

Health and eating trends influence demand for peanut butter, though shifts are generally short-term. Industry efforts to emphasize healthy characteristics like high protein and lack of additives, as well as new product flavors, can positively impact demand.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Imports comprise only 4.1% of domestic demand due to dominance of major US brands and peanut butter being a traditionally American food.
US peanut butter is known for quality, with most exports going to Canada and Mexico due to proximity. But exports still only account for 6.4% of revenue.

business_locations.location_description: The West region accounts for 28.1% of industry establishments, likely due to California's large agricultural output and proximity to key Pacific shipping routes.
The Southeast region, including major peanut-producing states like Georgia and Virginia, accounts for 15.5% of industry establishments.
Georgia, known for its peanut production, is home to 3.0% of industry establishments.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Like all food producers, operators in the Peanut Butter Production industry are subject to food safety oversight by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA).
At least 90% peanuts; accordingly, the FDA has enforced that lower-fat products whose composition fails to reach this benchmark must be labeled as peanut butter spreads instead of peanut butter.
In 2011, President Obama signed the Food Safety Modernization Act (FSMA) into law. The FSMA shifts the focus of the FDA's efforts from contamination management to contamination prevention.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The greatest threat to new entrants is the dominance of well-established brand name peanut butter producers.
Brand name producers have resources to dedicate to advertising and promotions that can protect market share.
Larger producers benefit from relationships with suppliers and distributors/retailers through contracts.

basis_points.basis_description: Competition based on quality and nutritional value has increased due to health concerns.
Introducing new varieties like all-natural, low-fat is essential to remain competitive.
Operators compete for retail shelf space through marketing of branded and private label products.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The three largest operators are expected to generate 80.9% of industry revenue in 2022.
Large players have acquired smaller competitors and private label producers to increase market share.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Runner peanuts are the most common variety used to produce peanut butter. In addition to the cost of peanuts, industry operators also require costly machinery to product peanut butter.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: For every $1.00 spent on wages, industry operators typically spend $0.20 in capital investment.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The Peanut Butter Production industry is subject to a high level of revenue volatility, driven primarily by fluctuating input costs and subsequent rises or reductions in product prices.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The Peanut Butter Production industry has not been disrupted by technological advancements. The industry relies on heavy industrial machinery, which can be automated to the benefit of the industry.
Technology use and investment will vary across industry operators based on their output quantities and subsequent economies of scale.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: The United States is the main producer of peanut butter so it does not have to contend much with imports.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Peanut butter sales are not dependent on the overall health of the economy as it is considered to be an inelastic good.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in areas with well-established infrastructure?
FAQs.answer: Larger operators, such as J.M Smucker's Co and Post Holdings, have engaged in significant acquisition activity, acquiring other large operators.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: One of the main inputs in the Peanut Production industry is peanuts. The price of peanuts is highly volatile as its prices are contingent on crop yield, weather and other factors.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to safeguard your company's proprietary information?
FAQs.answer: Certain large industry operators patent certain processes, packaging or products in order to keep their competitive advantage over competitors.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Larger industry operators are including automation into the production process in order to reduce their dependence on labor.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Given the salmonella outbreak of 2007 impacting Conagra Brands' peanut butter production, which resulted in a halt of peanut butter production for the company, other operators have become increasingly careful to meet health and safety requirements.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: The industry benefits from working with associations such as the American Peanut Council and Southern Peanut Growers, among others.

FAQs.question: How does your company's inventory turnover rate compare to your major competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Peanut butter producers are not typically concerned with their inventory's turnover rate given that peanut butter is shelf stable. Furthermore, larger operators typically have contracts with big box retailers such as Walmart. Producers know how much they need to produce to meet their contracts.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Larger operators typically benefit from economies of scale, enabling them to have significantly larger profit margins than smaller operators.

FAQs.question: What are the key attributes associated with your brand? Do you have multiple brands? If yes, which are the most popular?
FAQs.answer: Major companies with well-established brand names dominate this industry.

FAQs.question: What quality control processes do you have in effect? How can you improve the quality of your products?
FAQs.answer: Consumers demand the highest possible quality for all food products. Operators with access to high-quality inputs will likely be able to produce high-quality products.

FAQs.question: How large is your distribution network? How do you keep distribution costs down?
FAQs.answer: Companies need to establish relationships with wholesalers to keep costs down and assure timely, high-quality delivery of products to market. For small companies, the most cost-effective system may be self-distribution, bypassing wholesalers altogether.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by fluctuations in the price of key inputs like peanuts? How can you adapt as the index decreases?
FAQs.answer: Fluctuations in the price and availability of key raw material inputs, mainly peanuts, largely determine manufacturers' product pricing and can significantly affect profit margins.

FAQs.question: Do you offer a range of products to appeal to consumers' varying health consciousness? Have you seen an increase in sales of your healthier varieties?
FAQs.answer: Some forms of peanut butter are considered unhealthy because they contain added vegetable oils or sodium, which may lead to reduced demand as health consciousness rises.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising disposable income levels? How can you take advantage when disposable income increases?
FAQs.answer: Demand for peanut butter is not generally susceptible to changes in consumer spending; however, when consumers experience a rise in their disposable income, they are more willing to spend on higher-end brands.
